title: 110_s1184
content: The Act is titled the "Taunton, Massachusetts Special Resources Study Act" and includes findings. Congress finds that the city of Taunton, Massachusetts is home to 9 historic districts with nearly 100 properties on the National Register of Historic Places, including buildings of significant historical, cultural, and architectural value. Taunton Green is where the Sons of Liberty first raised the Liberty and Union Flag in 1774, sparking a movement leading to the American Revolution. Robert Treat Paine, a Taunton citizen, was also mentioned. Taunton, Massachusetts, home to historic districts with significant properties on the National Register of Historic Places. Robert Treat Paine, a Taunton citizen, was the first Attorney General of Massachusetts and a signer of the Declaration of Independence. Taunton's industrial area has seen innovations in industries like silver and paper manufacture, as well as shipbuilding. The Bristol County Courthouse Complex grounds were designed by Frederick Law Olmsted, known for designing important national sites. Main Street and Summer Street in Taunton connect historic districts with architecturally significant structures like Taunton City Hall and the Leonard Block building, showcasing 19th Century American architecture. The city and people of Taunton have preserved many historical and architectural treasures. Taunton, Massachusetts, founded in 1638, preserves artifacts, gravesites, and documents. It remains a significant destination for immigrants, contributing to Southeastern Massachusetts' diverse ethnic makeup. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines "city" as Taunton, Massachusetts, "Secretary" as the Secretary of the Interior, and "State" as Massachusetts. The Secretary, in consultation with State historic preservation officers and other organizations, will conduct a special resources study on designating historic buildings in Taunton as part of the National Park System. The study will include analysis on managing and preserving these areas under National Park Service management. The National Park Service will manage areas with cultural, historic, and natural resources representing US heritage. These areas reflect traditions, historical events, and provide opportunities for conservation, recreation, and education. The National Park Service can manage areas in partnership with various entities to develop a unit of the National Park System in line with local economic activity. The Secretary must submit a report to Congress within 3 fiscal years of funds being allocated for this Act, detailing study findings, recommendations, and addressing concerns of private landowners regarding designating certain structures as part of the National Park System.
